---
title: Managing App Secrets with Vault and Kubernetes
weight: 9100
description: How to integrate Vault and Kubernetes together to expose secrets in applications (Kubernetes) and manage secrets (Vault).
date: 2023-09-17
aliases:
---

# Managing App Secrets with Vault and Kubernetes

## Installing Vault (Dev Mode)

Using the Helm chart, we will switch Vault into dev mode. This ensures the vault
instance does no state management. Thus would lose all data on a restart.

1. Add the Vault Helm repository.

    ```sh
    helm repo add hashicorp https://helm.releases.hashicorp.com
    ```

1. Install Vault.

    ```sh
    helm install vault hashicorp/vault 
    --namespace vault \
    --set "server.dev.enabled=true" \
    --set "server.dev.devRootToken=${YOUR_TOKEN_VALUE}" \
    --set "ui.enabled=true" \
    --set "ui.serviceType=NodePort"
    ```

    > Depending on what your environment, NodePort may expose your Vault
    > interface inappropiatly. Consider this value before setting it.

    > Replace `${YOUR_TOKEN_VALUE}` with a secret you'd like to use for
    > accessing and managing Vault.

1. Verify Vault's status.

    ```sh
    kubectl exec --stdin=true \
        -n vault \
        --tty=true \
        vault-0 -- \
        vault status
    ```

    Since Vault is running in dev mode, the output should state:

    ```txt
    Initialized     true
    Sealed          false
    ```

## Understanding Vault Relationships

Key concepts in Vault include auth methods, roles, secrets, and policies. To
explain these, we'll start with a visualization of their relationships:

white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;">Auth Method</div></div></div></foreignObject><text x="70" y="234" fill="rgb(0, 0, 0)" font-family="Helvetica" font-size="12px" text-anchor="middle">Auth Method</text></switch></g><rect x="20" y="210" width="120" height="60" fill="rgb(255, 255, 255)" stroke="rgb(0, 0, 0)" pointer-events="all"/><g transform="translate(-0.5 -0.5)"><switch><foreignObject pointer-events="none" width="100%" height="100%" requiredFeatures="http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#Extensibility" style="overflow: visible; text-align: left;"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" style="display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 240px; margin-left: 21px;"><div data-drawio-colors="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); " style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;"><div style="display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;">Auth Method</div></div></div></foreignObject><text x="80" y="244" fill="rgb(0, 0, 0)" font-family="Helvetica" font-size="12px" text-anchor="middle">Auth Method</text></switch></g><rect x="10" y="300" width="120" height="60" fill="rgb(255, 255, 255)" stroke="rgb(0, 0, 0)" pointer-events="all"/><g transform="translate(-0.5 -0.5)"><switch><foreignObject pointer-events="none" width="100%" height="100%" requiredFeatures="http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#Extensibility" style="overflow: visible; text-align: left;"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" style="display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 330px; margin-left: 11px;"><div data-drawio-colors="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); " style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;"><div style="display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;">Secrets Engine</div></div></div></foreignObject><text x="70" y="334" fill="rgb(0, 0, 0)" font-family="Helvetica" font-size="12px" text-anchor="middle">Secrets Engine</text></switch></g><rect x="20" y="310" width="120" height="60" fill="rgb(255, 255, 255)" stroke="rgb(0, 0, 0)" pointer-events="all"/><g transform="translate(-0.5 -0.5)"><switch><foreignObject pointer-events="none" width="100%" height="100%" requiredFeatures="http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#Extensibility" style="overflow: visible; text-align: left;"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" style="display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 340px; margin-left: 21px;"><div data-drawio-colors="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); " style="box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;"><div style="display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;">Secrets Engine</div></div></div></foreignObject><text x="80" y="344" fill="rgb(0, 0, 0)" font-family="Helvetica" font-size="12px" text-anchor="middle">Secrets Engine</text></switch></g></g><switch><g requiredFeatures="http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#Extensibility"/><a transform="translate(0,-5)" xlink:href="https://www.drawio.com/doc/faq/svg-export-text-problems" target="_blank"><text text-anchor="middle" font-size="10px" x="50%" y="100%">Text is not SVG - cannot display</text></a></switch></svg>

In our setup today, we'll use a mapping of Kubernetes service accounts to vault
roles to determine the validity of a workload's identity. This will work by the
Pod sending its service account token (JWT) to Vault. Vault will then use the
Kubernetes
[TokenReview](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/authentication-resources/token-review-v1)
API to determine whether the token is in fact associated with the service
account. If so, Vault provides the calling Pod a token for the Vault role.

Without an associated policy, the role itself doesn't provide any access.
Policies specify access control (read, write, etc) against secrets. A role can
be associated with one or many policies. So, once a Vault role is properly
assumed, the Pod can access any secrets it can `read` via the role's associated
policy.

## Creating a Workload

This guide will use a busybox container, which has a service account,
`web-app-reader` attached to it.

1. Create a Service Account.

    ```sh
    kubectl create sa web-app-reader
    ```

1. Create a Deployment.

    ```yaml
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    metadata:
      name: busybox
    spec:
      replicas: 1
      selector:
        matchLabels:
          app: busybox
      template:
        metadata:
          labels:
            app: busybox
        spec:
          serviceAccountName: web-app-reader
          containers:
            - name: busybox
              image: busybox:latest
              command: ["/bin/sh"]
              args: ["-c", "sleep 1200"]
    ```

## Kubernetes Auth Provider

Configuring the [Kubernetes Auth
Provider](https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/auth/kubernetes) enables
Vault reach to Kubernetes to verify the integrity of a service account token and
details about which service account it maps to.

1. Enable Kubernetes-based auth.

    * CLI:

        ```sh
        kubectl exec -n vault vault-0 --\
            vault auth enable kubernetes
        ```

    * UI:

       ![](/images/vault-ui-k8s-base-auth.png) 

1. Point the Kubernetes-based auth at the API server.

    * CLI:

        ```sh
        kubectl exec -it -n vault vault-0 -- /bin/sh
        ```
        From within the `vault-0` pod:

        ```sh
        vault write auth/kubernetes/config \
            kubernetes_host="https://$KUBERNETES_PORT_443_TCP_ADDR:443"
        ```

        > `$KUBERNETES_PORT_443_TCP_ADDR` is an environment variable known to
        > the Pod.

    * UI:

        ![](/images/vault-ui-k8s-auth-kube-api.png)

        > The IP seen above may be different for your environment.

## Setting Up Secrets in Vault

In Vault, we need to create a secret and provide access to it for any workload
using the `web-app-reader` service account. The CLI and UI methods will be show
for each step.

1. Create a Secret in Vault.

    * CLI:
        
        ```sh
        kubectl exec -n vault vault-0 --\
            vault kv put secret/tokens/webapps \
            apiSecret="abc1234" \
            dbPassword="password"
        ```

        Once created, note the secret path in the output.

        ```
        ====== Secret Path ======
        secret/data/tokens/webapp
        ```

    * UI:

        ![](/images/vault-ui-create-secret.png)

1. Create a policy allowing read access to the secret.

    * CLI:

        ```sh
        kubectl exec -it -n vault vault-0 -- /bin/sh
        ```

        From within the pod, run:

        ```sh
        vault policy write web-readers - <<EOF
            path "secret/data/tokens/webapps" {
               capabilities = ["read"]
            }
        EOF
        ```

    * UI:

        ![](/images/vault-ui-policy.png)

1. Create a role, which binds to the Kubernetes service account `web-app-reader`
   and associates with the policy.

    * CLI:

       ```sh
       kubectl exec -n vault vault-0 --\
           vault write auth/kubernetes/role/web-app-reader \
           bound_service_account_names=web-app-reader \
           bound_service_account_namespaces=default \
           policies=web-readers \
           ttl=24h
       ```

    * UI:

        ![](/images/vauilt-ui-role.png)

        > Not shown in this screenshot is the Policies sections, containing
        > `web-readers`.

Everything is now in place from a Vault and Kubernetes perspective. The various
items created and their relationships are:

## Agent Injection

We can now setup the `busybox` Deployment to receive the `webapps` secret. The
first method we'll use is agent injection. This method has a lot of moving
pieces, but at its core it does the following.

1. Adds mutating webhook for all pods with vault-specific annotations.
1. Mutating webhook adds 1 init container and 1 sidecar container to the pod.
1. The init container fetches the secret initially and the sidecar can handles
   updates (e.g. rotations) and other functionality.

With this understanding, let's inject the secret.

1. Update the `busybox` deployment to look as follows:

    ```yaml
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    metadata:
      name: busybox
    spec:
      replicas: 1
      selector:
        matchLabels:
          app: busybox
      template:
        metadata:
          annotations:
             vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject: 'true'
             vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-status: 'update'
             vault.hashicorp.com/role: 'web-app-reader'
             vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-secret-webapp-secret.txt: 'secret/data/tokens/webapps'
             vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-template-webapp-secret.txt: |
                {{- with secret "secret/data/tokens/webapps" -}}
                API_SECRET:{{ .Data.data.apiSecret }}::{{ .Data.data.dbPassword }}
                {{- end -}}
          labels:
            app: busybox
        spec:
          serviceAccountName: web-app-reader
          containers:
            - name: busybox
              image: busybox:latest
              command: ["/bin/sh"]
              args: ["-c", "sleep 1200"]
    ```

1. Verify the secret data was made available.

    ```sh
    kubectl exec busybox-544d7fc9df-nqh5v \
        -c busybox -- \
        cat /vault/secrets/webapp-secret.txt
    ```

    This should output:

    ```txt
    API_SECRET:abc1234::password
    ```

## CSI Injection

Secret injection via CSI runs a daemonset on every node that communicates with
Vault on behalf of the application and mounts (ephemeral) secrets in the pod.
This alleviates the needs for running the vault-agent alongside each pod and
instead can be provided as a platform service to all workloads across the fleet.

1. If vault pre-exists, uninstall it.

    ```sh
    helm uninstall vault --namespace vault
    ```

1. If vault pre-exists, uninstall it.

    ```sh
    helm install vault hashicorp/vault \
    --namespace vault \
    --set "server.dev.enabled=true" \
    --set "server.dev.devRootToken=${YOUR_TOKEN_VALUE}" \
    --set "injector.enabled=false" \
    --set "csi.enabled=true" \
    --set "ui.enabled=true" \
    --set "ui.serviceType=NodePort"
    ```

1. Install the secrets store CSI driver.

    ```sh
    helm repo add \
        secrets-store-csi-driver \
        https://kubernetes-sigs.github.io/secrets-store-csi-driver/charts
    helm install csi \
        secrets-store-csi-driver/secrets-store-csi-driver \
        --namespace vault \
        --set syncSecret.enabled=true
    ```

1. Create a `SecretProviderClass` to support `busybox`.

    ```yaml
    apiVersion: secrets-store.csi.x-k8s.io/v1
    kind: SecretProviderClass
    metadata:
      name: vault-webapp
    spec:
      provider: vault
      secretObjects:
      - data:
        - key: apiSecret
          objectName: pass-for-webapp
        secretName: webapp-secret
        type: Opaque
      parameters:
        vaultAddress: "http://vault.vault.svc.cluster.local:8200"
        roleName: "web-app-reader"
        objects: |
          - objectName: "pass-for-webapp"
            secretPath: "secret/data/tokens/webapps"
            secretKey: "apiSecret"
    ```

1. Update busybox.

    ```yaml 
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    metadata:
      name: busybox
    spec:
      replicas: 1
      selector:
        matchLabels:
          app: busybox
      template:
        metadata:
          labels:
            app: busybox
        spec:
          serviceAccountName: web-app-reader
          containers:
            - name: busybox
              image: busybox:latest
              command: ["/bin/sh"]
              args: ["-c", "sleep 1200"]
              volumeMounts:
              - name: secrets-store-inline
                mountPath: "/mnt/secrets-store"
                readOnly: true
          volumes:
          - name: secrets-store-inline
            csi:
              driver: secrets-store.csi.k8s.io
              readOnly: true
              volumeAttributes:
                secretProviderClass: "vault-webapp"
    ```



## Extra Tips
